creator: heilong@bluebottle.com
text:
This config worked ok in apache 1.3:
    <Directory "/var/www/localhost/htdocs/forum">
        DirectoryIndex list
        SetHandler application/x-httpd-php
    </Directory>
I've got several PHP files without extension in that directory, and use
SetHandler to make apache run them with mod_php. The problem is, apache 2.0
tries to run the directory itself with mod_php (as seen by error log: [Fri Jul
01 19:35:11 2005] [error] [client 127.0.0.1] attempt to invoke directory
'/var/www/localhost/htdocs/forum/' as script, referer: http://localhost/)

I've worked around this by the following config, but the bug should be fixed.

    <Directory "/var/www/localhost/htdocs/forum">
        DirectoryIndex list
        <Files "?*">
            SetHandler application/x-httpd-php
        </Files>
    </Directory>

This works because Files "?*" doesn't match the directory itself.

Actually I'm wondering why do you think, this could be a bug. You configured
your own handler for the directory (and all stuff below), you got it. If you
meant only the files in the directory, you'd have configured it for the files
only. That's what you did finally. So where's the bug?
creator: nd@perlig.de
heilong@bluebottle.com
text:
First of all, it indeed didn't work on directories in Apache 1.3.
Then, the apache manual (http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_mime.html#sethandler)
says that this directive forces "all matching files". Since when directories can
be called files?

<quote>
When placed into an .htaccess file or a <Directory> or <Location>  section, this
directive forces all matching files to be parsed through the handler given by
handler-name. For example, if you had a directory you wanted to be parsed
entirely as imagemap rule files, regardless of extension, you might put the
following into an .htaccess file in that directory:
</quote>

I can say there is a bug because actual apache behaviour doesn't match the
behaviour documentation describes.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Despite that directories *are* files, albeit special ones, the documentation is
wrong anyway. Replace files with resources and you get it. Accepting this
documentation bug.

From: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/trunk/mod/core.html#sethandler

Note: because SetHandler overrides default handlers, normal behaviour such as handling of URLs ending in 
a slash (/) as directories or index files is suppressed.

I don't know when, but this appears to have been fixed.
